Posts.Content: May 5, 2007 09:16AM mkl48 wrote: That was the way it was once done. You would need to sign a zillion releases because of the "I woke up without my breast legal issues". My surgeon knew he probably had bad margins, we had discussed mast. But he did a lumpectomy, only for me to need a mast 3 weeks later. I too worry about the reactive effect and wish he had just done the mast ,he knew he would have to do. You would need to specify that any abnormality from in situ or maybe even atypical would trigger the OK even if the later pathology differed. Beth
Posts.Title: Breast dimpling: If you had it to do over.... 2verna2 2verna2

Posts.Content: May 5, 2007 09:09AM mkl48 wrote: The 2 main reasons for neo-chemo are to do a lumpectomy-chemo does not ensure clean margins and to see if the cancer is responsive. Currently there is no survival advantage either way. One does need a work up, but for some not knowing how well or not their cancer responded-mast first might be less anxiety producing.Beth

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2008 03:25PM - edited Mar 19, 2008 07:57PM by mkl48 Hi,  I read the info on weight  from MDA on the home page.Unfortunately there is no distinction between survival and disease free state.It is discouraging since his prognosis is dated from being both overweight and obese at dx let alone any gain from chemo or AI. There wasn't a significant difference in his outcomes from being 10 pounds overweight to being really obese.Many other obesity related illnesses show a ten to 15% weight lb loss is very helpful. He did a ten year study, but there is no info as to whether the women who started out overweight did  any better if they lost it or were they just"doomed" from the start. Do any of you researchers have data that weight loss really matters or does the cancer retain its aggressive nature even if there is weight loss.I do not know if he looked at Her status or ER +.But they were post men so probably ER+. Now the exercise data shows benefit for obese as well as best weight women. And isn't the diet info confusing that is posted on the home page. It does seem as though the whites are just not good for us even without added fat.Beth

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2008 12:04AM - edited Jan 15, 2008 01:00AM by mkl48 Tender and others, Just what do we eat? I have been eating both peanut butter and almonds so that I had a high fat source to better absorb Aromasin per study.AT this point it seems no suger, wheat , lentils, chickpeas-HUMMUS- or red meat. Then too dairy seems suspect.Apples with peel have to shown to reduce cancer,but maybe only for er- women. I really am confused because my oncologist has never mentioned these food related sources of estrogen. Let's add eggs because of cholesterol. Breakfast is a whole new question- no toast, oatmeal ,most cereals or coffee. For the record what about the estrogenic properties of the phyto and Xeno estogenS you omitted?Beth  Just did a little more reading- add raisins and prunes to the no list. Even broccoli, citrus and tomato can be considered estrogenic foods.Those almonds may lower blood sugar which when high can increase risk. The apples lose their so called anti-cancer properties when peeled by the way. I wonder what Allyson has to add since her diet is based on daily consumption of many of these foods.  So the chemo we ER+ women took may have little value and the healthy diets may be increasing our estrogen while the AIs are adding belly fat,raising insulin and increasing testosterone so that androgen dependent tumors can have a field day. What then is the best diet-Is there any research in people-not mice??  COULD IT BE THAT THE NEGATIVE OUTCOME FROM THE 2 LARGE  DIETARY STUDIES WHICH DEMONSTARTED LITTLE BENEFIT FOR ER+ WOMEN EITHER ON A LOW FAT DIET OR 8+ SERVING VEGETABLE DIET WAS A CONSEQUENCE OF SUBSTITUTING OR ADDING ESTROGENIC FOODS?

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2008 03:04PM - edited Jan 15, 2008 04:24PM by mkl48 Tender, We have moved away from the theme of this discussion which centered on food that might not raise red flags. While studies have been done on soy and flax, there is probably even less consensus about the impact of the peanut butter toast, almond snack, coffee break and hummus  veggie sandwich, variations of which would make up a low fat high flavonoid diet  ABOVE PARAGRAPH WRITTEN SECOND Found and bookmarked the referenced article. Note my plea above about human clinical investigation, not mice, transgenic or otherwise. Even the chapter on Tamoxifin and soy-flax had contradictory outcomes. Maybe because i had lobular I am just as concerned about the less obvious, sneaky sources from almonds to parabens.I really like what the Olay Regenerist line has done for my aging complexion- just full of parabens!!!.   Beth
